ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have a solid understanding of antitrust law and analysis.
This course is an excellent introduction to the various types of antitrust cases that the DOJ and FTC prosecutes. It is primarily an economics course but we do discuss relevant laws as well.
I learned a lot about the various types of anticompetitive behavior and antitrust enforcement.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course's interdisciplinary nature is great.
Very well taught and organized. The professor is very intelligent. The grading and workload is very fair.
The strength lies in the breadth and depth of the material. The weakness is that some theoretical economic materials are too deep even for people who studied intermediate micro/macro.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Learning about each case was fun because you end up learning about the ins and outs of the industries as well. The economics is interesting and fairly straightforward. The work is fun and engaging.

Overall great class. Prof Scott Morton is incredibly knowledgeable. Definitely a class where you get out what you put in. The homework assignments were a bit annoying - there were four psets on 'R' which I had never used before. Other than that, a fair midterm and final and an AWESOME final project on a relevant antitrust case. Would recommend!
This is an excellent course on anticompetitive behavior, something that will never be taught at Yale College.
